data.title: Multi-root SCM constantly polls git
data.body:
If vscode is in the foreground or background it constantly polls git for the status of each folder every few seconds. I can reproduce this on a workspace containing 2 folders, both of which have no untracked files, clean index, on master and nothing running to mutate anything in the repo. If I instead just open a folder (instead of a multi-root workspace) vscode does not poll git, even when in the foreground. Note: It does seem to poll git a few times in single folder mode, but stops after a bit of time.

I created this script on my `PATH` called `git` to monitor usage of git:

```sh
#!/bin/sh
echo "$PPID $PWD $@" >> /tmp/git.log
exec /usr/local/bin/git "$@"
```

I see entries like this regularly, the PPID is `code-insiders`:

```
95329 /Users/keegan/src/go status -z -u
95329 /Users/keegan/src/go symbolic-ref --short HEAD
95329 /Users/keegan/src/go rev-parse master
95329 /Users/keegan/src/go rev-parse --symbolic-full-name --abbrev-ref master@{u}
95329 /Users/keegan/src/go rev-list --left-right master...origin/master
95329 /Users/keegan/src/go for-each-ref --format %(refname) %(objectname)
95329 /Users/keegan/src/go remote --verbose
```


- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.16.0-insider (4f32007a5e20f181c675fefa82ff6115c785bb23, 2017-08-28T13:47:37.580Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
material-icon-theme|PKi|2.2.0
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
vscode-dash|dee|1.7.0
python|don|0.7.0
tslint|eg2|0.17.0
Go|luk|0.6.63
MagicPython|mag|1.0.12
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.2.0
vscode-multiclip|sle|0.1.2
sourcegraph|sou|1.0.9



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a workspace in the latest insiders build
2. Notice the "checking" badge appear regularly on SCM viewlet
3. Tab away
4. Monitor git usage via extra script, or via `sudo fs_usage -f filesys git` on MacOS.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Find in Files only searches in opened files in workspace
data.body:
Version 1.15.1
Commit 41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959
Date 2017-08-16T17:16:27.618Z
Shell 1.6.6
Renderer 56.0.2924.87
Node 7.4.0
Architecture x64

1. Ctrl-Shift-F (Search in files). Type something I know it's in my source files.
2. VSCode does not find anything.
3. Open one source file
4. Repeat the search, it does find the term within the opened file.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

This is happening on certain projects, on other it works fine. Settings are exactly the same on both working and non-working projects.

This is my settings.json:

```
{

	},

        "**/*.o": true,
        "**/*.d": true
	},

} 
```

Works on /home/leandro/Lore/ElfinThread/ElfinSales3/server; it does not work on /home/leandro/Desarrollo/hsl/working, so directory names are not likely the problem. Both are C++ projects.

data.title: Test: new API for themable colors in extensions
data.body:
Tests #14309:

Complexity 3:

- [x] any os @chrmarti 
- [x] any os @rebornix 

A new 'colors' contribution point got added that lets extensions define new colors. These colors can be defined in themes and users settings and referenced for decorations and status bar contributions
```
        "colors": [{
            "id": "superstatus.error",
            "description": "Color or the error message in the status bar.",
            "defaults": {
                "dark": "#FF0000",
                "light": "errorForeground",
                "highContrast": "errorForeground"
            }
        }]
```
Defaults can be actual colors or a reference to an existing color.

- create an extension that defines a custom color
- use the color in a decoration or a status bar item
- test that the color can be set in a user theme or in the user settings
- test that changing the color value automatically updates it in the UI (no code needed)

data.title: Test: Keeping the undo history when the file changes on disk
data.body:
Test plan item for #2908 (PR #29655)

Complexity: 3
- [x] any OS @aeschli 
- [x] any OS @isidorn 

---

Test that if you do some changes on a file and save the file, and then the file gets changed on disk via some other program, we (as before) automatically update to show the disk content, but (unlike before) the undo stack is maintained.

Some edge cases: 
 * a large (log-style) file with a program that logs to it every N seconds. Please check that we don't run OOM due to the undo stack.
 * a change on disk that is large (goes from a file to an empty file, goes from an empty file to a file with 20MB, etc.)

data.title: Test: Extension Host Restarting
data.body:
Test plan item for #32768

Complexity: 3
- [x] windows @egamma
- [x] linux @mjbvz 
- [x] osx @weinand

Use task manager or the command line to identify and kill the extension host process. An error message should appear informing that the extension host has crashed. Immediately as this happens, all the workbench state should become clean of all extension host driven things: e.g. squiggles should disappear, status items should disappear, code lens should disappear, etc. etc.

An action is available in that error message and the error message cannot be dismissed (as before). You can execute "Restart Extension Host" from that error message and the extension host should restart and **all previously activated extensions should activate again** and the UI state should readjust, sort of like on the start-up case, i.e. squiggles appear, status bar items appear, etc. etc.

Please try to play with a window where the extension host was restarted. Everything should work as if the window was reloaded.

data.title: Test: Smooth Scrolling
data.body:
Test plan item for #4606 (PR #25286)

Complexity: 3
- [x] windows @roblourens 
- [x] linux @Tyriar 
- [x] OSX @jrieken 

Configure `editor.smoothScrolling: true`. Please check that the editor animates to a certain scroll location in various cases (e.g. page up, page down, ctrl+home, next diff, etc.) and please help in identifying the cases where it should not animate. e.g. code lens getting computed and their space getting reserved.

The smooth scrolling should also kick in when using a physical mouse with a wheel, but not when using a touchpad. This uses a classifier which might be incorrect. If you have a device where we extra animate on top of an inertia-ready device or where we don't animate on a mouse wheel, please let me know so I can ask you for some additional information.

data.title: Test: Extension Recommendation Improvements
data.body:
Complexity 2

- [x] anyOs @joaomoreno  
- [x] anyOs @dbaeumer  


**Testing Telemetry for the Recommendation Pop up**
1. Pick any of the extensions from the `extensionImportantTips` https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-distro/blob/master/quality/insider/product.json#L63
2. Uninstall it if you have it installed, reload VS Code
3. Open the file corresponding to the extension you picked, you will get the recommendation pop up
4. Choose `Show Recommendations` and test that an event by the name `extensionRecommendations:popup` is fired. The `customDimenstions.userReaction` should have the user reaction
5. Repeat steps 1 to 3. Close the pop up. Same event should get fired. The `customDimenstions.userReaction` should have the user reaction
6. Repeat steps 1 to 3. Escape the pop up. Same event should get fired. The `customDimenstions.userReaction` should have the user reaction

**Testing Telemetry for installing an extension**
1. Search for an extension and install it
2. Go to the recommended view and install one of the recommended extensions.
3. An event by the name `extensionGallery:install` should get logged for both. `customDimensions.source` should denote recommendations for the latter

**Testing Recommendations based on executables**
1. Install azure cli or any of the other exes in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-distro/blob/master/quality/insider/product.json#L111
2. Reload VS Code and go to the recommendations view
3. You should be able to see corresponding recommendations as per https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-distro/blob/master/quality/insider/product.json#L111

**Testing expiry on file based recommendations**
1. In dev tools, find  `extensionsassistant/recommendations`in the local storage
2. Extensions there will be showing up in your recommendations view. The numbers associated with them are the the date time in the form of number of milliseconds elapsed since 1 January 1970 00:00:00 UTC.
3. Update the storage for any one of them such that the date time is more than 7 days old. (Subtract 1000 * 60 * 60 * 24 *8)
4. Reload VS Code. That particular extension should not show up anymore

data.title: Test: Multi root support in the Go extension
data.body:
Complexity 3

- [x] anyOs @alexandrudima 
- [x] anyOs @sandy081 

Set up:

If you haven't setup Go before, 
1. Install [Go](https://golang.org/doc/install#install)
2. Setup GOPATH
    1. Choose a folder where you will be having the Go projects
    2. Add env variable GOPATH with value as the above folder path
    3. Create 3 folders "src", "bin" and "pkg"
3. Run `go get github.com/golang/example/hello`

- Install the Go extension via vsix from https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-go/blob/multi-root/Go-multiroot.vsix
- Run the command `Go: Install/Update Tools`
- Now your $GOPATH/src will have multiple Go projects, open any of them multi root set up and test few of the features from the Smoke Test wiki https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-go/wiki/Smoke-Test
- Play with the settings at user/workspace/folder level. All the settings except the `go.useLanguageServer` and `go.languageServerFlags` can be set up at folder level

> Note: the word "workspace" in the settings value (for build/lint/vet/test on save) or in the commands (like Go: Test workspace) will mean the folder and not the multi root workspace

Log bugs under a single issue at https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-go/issues

Test: HTML tag auto close
data.body:
Test for #2246

Complexity 2

- [x] any os @joaomoreno 
- [x] any os @rebornix 

In a HTML file

1. typing the `>` of `<sometag>` will add the closing tag `</sometag>`.
2. typing '/' of `</` will also close the tag.

- test that this works also for tags with attributes
- test that selfclosing tags (e.g.` img`, `br`) will not be closed
- test that the closing tag name matches the last unclosed tag
- test that this can be turned off with setting `html.autoClosingTags`

data.title: SCM: Need a better "no repositories" view
Test vscode-tslint in the multi folder setup
data.body:
Complexity: 4

OS:

- [x] any OS @ramya-rao-a 

## Setup

- Download the attached extension [tslint-2.0.0.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/1258251/tslint-2.0.0.zip)
- rename it from `.zip` to `.vsix`. 
- Install the extensions using `code-insiders --install-extension tslint-2.0.0.vsix`.

## Test Setup

- single folder setup
- multi root folder setup

An example test-setup can be found here
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-tslint/tree/master/tslint-tests

## Test

- single folder setup, tslint should still work in the single folder setup
- multi folder setup
  - vscode-tslint supports different tslint versions in different folders, install different versions and test that the linting still works. The tslint output channel will show you which version of tslint was loaded.
  - the settings of vscode-tslint are all scoped to resources and they should work in the multi root folder setup.
  - create tslint.json file using the `tslint: create tslint.json` command

Interesting settings:
- tslint.enable
- tslint.nodePath

data.title: Git: Allow to configure location of ssh keys

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro Insider Slow

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Delete `%USERPROFILE%\.ssh`
2. Launch VSCode
3. Look at `%USERPROFILE%`, notice that there is now an empty `.ssh` folder.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

I suspect this is being caused by VSCode's git integration, though I was unable to figure out how to redirect to where my SSH keys _actually_ live (`%APPDATA%\ssh`).

data.title: Test: JS/TS extract method refactoring
data.body:
Complexity: 3

- [x] any @seanmcbreen
- [x] any @dbaeumer  

# Overview
TS 2.5 brings an extract method refactoring option. This is a code action that users can trigger for the current expression of for selected code

# Testing
Focus testing on the integration and UI experience in VS Code (since the functionality of 'extract method' is out of our control anyway). 
Try browsing around some JS and TS code and triggering extract method. It should work for the current expression if you don't have a selection, and for the current selection if it can be extracted

**Note of filing issues**
I suspect most of the issues encountered with this test pass will be upstream TS issues. In those cases, please file the issue against TS directly to save time: https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/new
 
# Known issues
- Extract method does not trigger rename automatically. This is tracked for the next TS servicing release: https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/17852

data.title: Test: Multiroot inferred JS/TS project support
data.body:
**Size**: 2
**OS**
- [x] Linux @joaomoreno 
- [x] Mac @chrmarti 
- [x] Windows @egamma 

# Overview
Loose JS and TS files should now be grouped into an inferred for project per folder. Previously, all loose files were added to the same inferred project

# Testing
1. Create a workspace with two empty folders. 
1. In each folder, create a js file.
1. Set a global in one of the js files: `var abc = 123`
1. In the other folder, verify that `abc` does not show up in the suggestions. `abc` should only be suggested for js files in the original folder

# Other cases to try
- Create a jsconfig. Once a js file is part of the jsconfig, it should be in its own project
- Try a workspace with two folders where the second folder is a subfolder of the first. In this case, we create a single inferred project for both.
